segment.source: Converting WDK 8.1 Projects to WDK 10
segment.target: Converting WDK 8.1 Projects to WDK 10

segment.source: This topic describes how to convert a driver project that was created using Microsoft Visual Studio 2013 and Windows Driver Kit (WDK) 8.1 to a driver project that builds in Microsoft Visual Studio 2015 with the Windows Driver Kit (WDK) 10.
segment.target: This topic describes how to convert a driver project that was created using Microsoft Visual Studio 2013 and Windows Driver Kit (WDK) 8.1 to a driver project that builds in Microsoft Visual Studio 2015 with the Windows Driver Kit (WDK) 10.

segment.source: Visual Studio 2015 has new compiler warnings and errors.
segment.target: Visual Studio 2015 has new compiler warnings and errors.

segment.source: Even if your driver project built with no errors in Visual Studio 2013, you might see errors when you build it in Visual Studio 2015.
segment.target: Even if your driver project built with no errors in Visual Studio 2013, you might see errors when you build it in Visual Studio 2015.

segment.source: Use these steps to convert the projects in a driver solution.
segment.target: Use these steps to convert the projects in a driver solution.

segment.source: In Visual Studio 2015, open the legacy driver solution.
segment.target: In Visual Studio 2015, open the legacy driver solution.

segment.source: Visual Studio automatically runs ProjectUpgradeTool to convert the projects in this solution.
segment.target: Visual Studio automatically runs ProjectUpgradeTool to convert the projects in this solution.

segment.source: You can also run this tool from the command line.
segment.target: You can also run this tool from the command line.

segment.source: By default, when you install the WDK, ProjectUpgradeTool.exe installs in Windows Kits\\10\\bin\\x86.
segment.target: By default, when you install the WDK, ProjectUpgradeTool.exe installs in Windows Kits\\10\\bin\\x86.

segment.source: Visual Studio opens a Review Solution Actions dialog with the title Upgrade VC++ Compiler and Libraries.
segment.target: Visual Studio opens a Review Solution Actions dialog with the title Upgrade VC++ Compiler and Libraries.

segment.source: Click OK and Visual Studio attempts to upgrade all projects in the solution.
segment.target: Click OK and Visual Studio attempts to upgrade all projects in the solution.

segment.source: If you see a File Modification Detected dialog, choose Reload All.
segment.target: If you see a File Modification Detected dialog, choose Reload All.

segment.source: In the Solution Explorer pane, right-click the driver project name and choose Properties.
segment.target: In the Solution Explorer pane, right-click the driver project name and choose Properties.

segment.source: Click the Configuration Manager button.
segment.target: Click the Configuration Manager button.

segment.source: In the Active solution configuration list, choose <New...>.
segment.target: In the Active solution configuration list, choose <New...>.

segment.source: Type a name and copy the settings from a Windows 8.1 project context.
segment.target: Type a name and copy the settings from a Windows 8.1 project context.

segment.source: Click OK.
segment.target: Click OK.

segment.source: Typically, the converted solution contains two configuration profiles, one for debug (testing) and one for release.
segment.target: Typically, the converted solution contains two configuration profiles, one for debug (testing) and one for release.

segment.source: To create a similar environment with WDK 10, simply choose <New...> twice.
segment.target: To create a similar environment with WDK 10, simply choose <New...> twice.

segment.source: To create a debug profile, copy from the Win 8.1 Debug profile.
segment.target: To create a debug profile, copy from the Win 8.1 Debug profile.

segment.source: To create a release profile, copy from the Win 8.1 Release profile.
segment.target: To create a release profile, copy from the Win 8.1 Release profile.

segment.source: In WDK versions prior to WDK 10, your driver solution always needed a package project.
segment.target: In WDK versions prior to WDK 10, your driver solution always needed a package project.

segment.source: In WDK 10, you only need a package project if you are including multiple drivers in a driver package.
segment.target: In WDK 10, you only need a package project if you are including multiple drivers in a driver package.

segment.source: Use the following guidelines:
segment.target: Use the following guidelines:

segment.source: If you have only one driver in the solution and a package project exists, delete it.
segment.target: If you have only one driver in the solution and a package project exists, delete it.

segment.source: If you have more than one driver in the solution, ensure that your solution contains a package project.
segment.target: If you have more than one driver in the solution, ensure that your solution contains a package project.

segment.source: Then, for each driver project in the solution, open project properties and navigate to Configuration Properties > Driver Settings.
segment.target: Then, for each driver project in the solution, open project properties and navigate to Configuration Properties > Driver Settings.

segment.source: Set BuildPackage to No.
segment.target: Set BuildPackage to No.

segment.source: If you are building from the command line, set /p:SupportsPackaging=false.
segment.target: If you are building from the command line, set /p:SupportsPackaging=false.

segment.source: Again in driver project properties, choose Properties.
segment.target: Again in driver project properties, choose Properties.

segment.source: Navigate to Configuration Properties > Driver Settings > General > Target OS Version.
segment.target: Navigate to Configuration Properties > Driver Settings > General > Target OS Version.

segment.source: Select Windows 10.
segment.target: Select Windows 10.

segment.source: Verify that Target Platform is set to Desktop, and build the solution.
segment.target: Verify that Target Platform is set to Desktop, and build the solution.

segment.source: Fix any errors that occur.
segment.target: Fix any errors that occur.

segment.source: Once the solution builds successfully, change Target Platform to Universal.
segment.target: Once the solution builds successfully, change Target Platform to Universal.

segment.source: Build the solution again.
segment.target: Build the solution again.

segment.source: At this point, the only errors are from the ApiValidator tool, which checks if the driver calls any non-universal functionality.
segment.target: At this point, the only errors are from the ApiValidator tool, which checks if the driver calls any non-universal functionality.

segment.source: Replace any calls to non-universal DDIs with calls to universal DDIs.
segment.target: Replace any calls to non-universal DDIs with calls to universal DDIs.

segment.source: For more information about ApiValidator, see Validating Universal Windows drivers.
segment.target: For more information about ApiValidator, see Validating Universal Windows drivers.

segment.source: To learn how to determine the target platform for a given DDI, see Target platform on MSDN driver reference pages.
segment.target: To learn how to determine the target platform for a given DDI, see Target platform on MSDN driver reference pages.
